meaning_mnemonic: A single drop (丶) is just water. But as soon as there are three, rising higher and higher, you know what's coming. A <radical>tsunami</radical>! Think of those drops as wave crests. Three whole tsunami waves, stacking up? That's a big tsunami.
See the slide going into the dirt? What appears to be a slide here is actually a <radical>coffin</radical>, sliding into the dirt to be buried.
You know <radical>Wolverine</radical> from the X-Men? He has three claws that come out of his hand whenever he needs to fight, not at all unlike the radical you see here.
You have 十 plus 十 (never mind that the left one is kinda curvy)... What do you get when you add these two kanji together? You get <radical>twenty</radical>.
This is the radical for <radical>meat</radical>. What's meat-like about this? Think of a nice square slab of meat with some beautiful 人-shaped marbling lines in it. Seeing it now? Mmm, meat.

Remember the eye radical? Imagine that's your eye now, and there's a drop of paint falling into it, making your eye color unique. Now it's what makes you you. It's what makes you your <radical>self</radical>.

In prison, dreaming in bed is the only way to see <radical>color</radical>. Picture a dark, dank cell with four gray walls. Now imagine the colorful dreamscapes your bed would take you to every night. What a contrast! That's why a prison bed = color.

You have the radicals for loiter, two, and barb. Someone who uses two barbs on you while you're loitering really wants you to <radical>GO</radical>!! GO on, stop loitering outside of my convenience store, ya dang kids!

You have the legs of a bird with wings outspread, landing in the mouth of her nest to rest. And when does she go back to rest? When the sun sets in the <radical>west</radical>! Imagine all the birds flying home as the sun sets. That's why this radical means west.

You could also see this as pi coming out of a mouth. Why would a mouth be talking about pi? Probably to figure out the curvature of the sun's path as it moves across the sky — to the west, always to the west!

This looks like something hooked around the corner of a mouth — it's a <radical>lip ring</radical>! Use your imagination, because it's either a giant lip ring or a very small mouth. It's angular because kanji prefer straight lines, but try to picture it as the kind of studded, angular lip ring your trendy friend wore in high school.
This radical is a <radical>scooter</radical>. See the handlebars and the little light? And there's a platform at the bottom you can stand or sit on (if it's one of those nice motorized scooters).

This is the radical for <radical>axe</radical>, since it looks like one. The two horizontal strokes are the head, the long left line is the whole edge of its blade, and the vertical line in the middle is its short handle. Kind of a strange axe, I admit, but an axe is an axe.
There are a bunch of lines coming out of a mouth. Think of them as speech lines in a little speech bubble. Those lines represent the things you <radical>say</radical>.

Underneath that hat are two bars of <radical>gold</radical>, but under those there are some spikes. This is some kind of trap for people who try to take your gold. And why else would you make a trap? Everyone wants to protect their gold.
The towel is getting soaked with drops of liquid. That's because it's <radical>rain</radical>ing. Get your towels and other clothes inside before they get soaked through from this rain!

You have life on top of the moon (ignore that life is missing its little slide on the left side). What would life on the moon look like? Well, first of all, they have no air, so they probably look pretty <radical>blue</radical> from asphyxiation. When you meet them, it turns out you're right. They're a civilization of blue people. Imagine them all living up there, being blue and Smurfy.

See the <radical>mustache</radical> going around the mouth? Man, I wish I could grow a sweet mustache like this. (Sure, the mustache looks a lot like the head radical here, but just imagine it as a mustache this time!)
This is a very oddly shaped <radical>key</radical>, but it's a key nonetheless.

See the person running (to the right)? That's why this is the radical for <radical>run</radical>. Just don't confuse this with foot (足). The head in this one has streaks around it because the person is running so fast.

A rice paddy and some dirt — dirt roads, in fact, because this is a <radical>village</radical>. Small villages like this are mostly rice paddies and dirt (roads), you know? You could even think of this as a bird's-eye view of a village.

Under the hat there are two people <radical>meet</radical>ing in private. Look at them huddled up in there. They must have a reason to want to meet in such a private place, but that's not for you to judge. Maybe next time you have to meet with someone you'll hide under a hat with them too.

Think of an old-style <radical>lantern</radical>. It's in a box-shaped holder lined with rice paper and sits on four legs (you can only see two from this angle though). You can imagine people using these before electricity, right? That's why this radical is a lantern.
This radical already looks like a pair of rectangular <radical>feathers</radical>, right? I guess those short lines in each feather are like the filaments of the feathers.

Here we have the ground radical, with something underneath it. What likes lying in the ground, covered in mud? A <radical>pig</radical>! Use your imagination and see if you can find the head near the top, the piggy tail at the bottom right, and the little piglets on the left, nestling up to this mama pig.

When you're in prison, your only task is to count every <radical>angle</radical> in your cell. You count the angles of the walls and ceiling over and over again to pass the time. How many angles could there be in a room with four walls? Picture it and try to count those angles now.

See that lid on top? It's actually a flying saucer. "Take me to your leader," say the aliens inside, arriving from a strange-looking moon. When do you think you'd see something like this? At <radical>night</radical>. When people see UFOs or the moon, it's usually night. That's why this is the night radical.

On the top part of the head (冂) radical, there is a horn radical with one extra spike in the middle. This is a horned helmet with one extra spike. Who were famous for having horned helmets like that? The Vikings! That's why this radical is called <radical>Viking</radical>.

This looks like a stick-figure foot on the left kicking at something, which makes it the radical for <radical>kick</radical>. See the shin and foot swinging up for the kick? You can think of that part on the right as the edge of a ball that's about to be kicked.
